awd_titl_txt: Function and Regulation of Leptin in Mediating Stress-induced Energy Expenditure
awd_abstract_narration:
Leptin is an important hormone involved in a wide range of physiological processes.  Despite a wealth of literature regarding the role of leptin in regulating energy expenditure in mammals, much less is known about the metabolic functions in other vertebrates. To better understand the evolution of this important hormone, the studies supported by this award will identify the metabolic action(s) and regulation of two leptin paralogs (Leptin A and Leptin B) in the tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus), a well-established endocrine and osmoregulatory model. The project will assess the metabolic and endocrine responses associated with stress-induced leptin signaling, functionally evaluate the metabolic effects of two leptins, and identify mechanisms which elicit the leptin response. Further, these studies will evaluate regulatory interactions of leptin with other stress-induced metabolic hormones (e.g. catecholamines, glucocorticoids) as part of the integrated endocrine stress response. In addition to advancing knowledge of leptin biology and control of metabolism in vertebrates, the project will incorporate graduate, undergraduate and high school students in research activities with a focus on developing an understanding of experimental designs, whole animal physiology, molecular and cell biology and endocrinology. The Principal Investigator will also work with the Science House at NCSU, and the NC Mathematics and Science Education Network Pre-College Program, to enhance K-12 STEM education and the recruitment of under-represented students into life sciences programs. A second outreach component will be provided through the Nature Research Center at the NC Museum of Natural Sciences (Daily Planet Broadcast) to develop teaching modules to foster greater public interest in science and the biology of fishes. Studies of stress related energy expenditure in tilapia, one of the fastest growing food sectors and a prominent source of animal protein worldwide, can improve management practices for culturing this fish and others.

This project will make two key advances toward understanding leptin biology in vertebrates. First, using a comparative teleost model a detailed understanding of the function(s) of leptin in regulating metabolism in ectotherms will be provided. Secondly, these studies will establish a critical role for leptin in mediating stress responses. These studies will determine the function and regulation of multiple leptins in teleost fishes. Moreover, examination of two leptin paralogs may reveal sub- or neo-functionalization of a major cytokine hormone following the teleostean (3R) genome duplication event, providing an important case study for understanding divergent gene fates. Collectively, these studies will provide a fundamental link between leptin, metabolism and catabolic stress in vertebrates. Results from the studies will be disseminated through publication in peer-reviewed journals and through presentations at scientific meetings.

por.por_cntn:
Leptin is an important hormone involved in a wide range of physiological processes. Despite a wealth of literature regarding the role of leptin in regulating energy expenditure in mammals, much less is known about the metabolic functions in other vertebrates. To better understand the evolution of this important hormone, this project identified the metabolic action(s) and regulation of leptin in the tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus), a well-established endocrine and osmoregulatory model. Through this project a substantial amount of knowledge has been gained on leptin biology in vertebrates including identity of new metabolic functions, conserved actions and regulatory mechanisms by which leptin controls energetically demanding physiological processes including those associated with the adaptive stress response.  

Studies demonstrate that leptin produced primarily by the liver (fat in mammals) is a catabolic hormone that suppresses appetite and increases in response to various stressors in tilapia. As part of meeting the metabolic challenge of the stressor, leptin mobilizes glucose, likely in part through the breakdown of glycogen stores. It appears to have little effect on gluconeogenesis or production of new glucose. Leptin secretion increases in response to epinephrine and cortisol and hence may integrate with these classic endocrine stress factors to promote catabolic processes essential to meet the energetic demands associated with restoration of homeostasis.

Basal cellular gene networks regulated by leptin were also characterized using transcriptomic, machine learning and neural network analyses (artificial intelligence) tools (>1700 differentially expressed genes).  A hypoxia sensitive pathway was one of many that was identified as leptin responsive. Based on this, it was discovered that leptin stimulates glycolysis, one of the most ancient metabolic pathways central to anaerobic and aerobic respiration, processes critical for producing cellular energy. Additional studies found leptin increases with hypoxia and suppresses cellular oxygen consumption or metabolic rate. Taken together the research suggests leptin may play an important role in the cellular hypoxic response and the adaptive stress response generally, such as with fasting, by reducing cellular oxygen consumption and conserving energy while stimulating anaerobic respiration, the latter being particularly important when ambient oxygen levels are low. 

Overall, the project has provided important insights on the role of leptin in regulating glucose homeostasis and metabolism. Additional work led to the discovery that teleosts possess an insulin-leptin axis that may contribute to regulating glucose balance between the fed and fasted state, although the relationship is likely much more dynamic in teleosts compared with mammals.  

Structural growth and reproduction are physiologically demanding processes that require substantial energetic input, the lack of which can result in the suppression of one or both of these systems. Leptin may serve as a metabolic gate for pubertal onset as it rises with the initiation of sexual maturation. Evidence from this project also contributes to the current framework of understanding the endocrine mechanisms that may drive stress-related suppression of gonadal growth, as well as possible mechanisms underlying sexually dimorphic growth in normal non-stress contexts. Research demonstrates leptin may contribute to sustaining skeletal growth through inhibition of estrogen-sensitive vitellogenesis and stimulation of insulin-like growth factors while estradiol may enhance vitellogenesis and promote reproductive growth, in part, through antagonization of leptin activity. It is speculated that this effect may be associated with limiting energy partitioning to reproduction in instances of negative energy balance when leptin has been shown to increase. Overall, the research provides novel evidence suggesting leptin may serve as a context-dependent mediator of energy investment into the expensive processes of somatic and gonadal growth. 

Collectively, the project provides an improved understanding of the role of leptin in stress related energy expenditure and metabolism in tilapia, one of the fastest growing food sectors and a prominent source of animal protein worldwide. The knowledge gained from this project contributes to the basic framework from which culture technologies for this fish and others could potentially be improved.

To enhance workforce development in STEM disciplines, the project provided training on state-of-the art technologies to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students as well as postdoctoral fellows, including those from underrepresented groups. To foster greater public interest in science various outreach activities were undertaken in this project to educate hundreds of youths and citizens on science and its importance to society and health, food production, and fish and wildlife biology.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Russell J Borski
